persona.name: Adam Kamara

occupation.title: Preschool child / dependent
occupation.description: Adam's 'work' is play, exploration, and early learning. He is responsible for simple age-appropriate tasks: putting away toys after play when reminded, bringing small items to adults (water cup, sandals), helping fetch light things for his mother, and participating in group singing or tidy-up routines at the playschool. He practices basic gross motor skills—running, kicking a ball, climbing low steps—and is developing fine motor skills with crayons, blocks, and simple puzzles. Caregivers encourage turn-taking and listening skills but discipline is gentle and often consists of redirection. Adam does not earn money; he sometimes helps his parents by handing small goods at the family stall when allowed for a short time as a playful 'helper.'

persona.residence: Freetown, Sierra Leone (urban neighborhood, near a busy market and a community center)
persona.education: No formal primary education completed. Attends a local community nursery/playschool 2-3 times a week when caretakers can afford the small fee or when a neighbor can escort him. At home he receives informal early learning: counting to 10, singing nursery rhymes in Krio and simple English words, and practicing coarse drawing and cutting with safety scissors. He is toilet-trained during the day but still uses diapers for naps and occasionally at night.
long_term_goals: Seen through the eyes of caregivers: for Adam to start and complete primary school and learn to read and write in both Krio-influenced English and Standard English.
For Adam to stay healthy through childhood and avoid repeated serious illness.
For Adam to be able to help the family in the future—either by getting a steady job, becoming a skilled tradesperson, or playing football well enough to gain local recognition.
For Adam to be confident in social situations and able to speak up at school and in his community.
For Adam to retain close ties with extended family and respect elders and local customs.
persona.style: Talkative in comfortable settings, but initially shy with strangers. Speaks Krio as his dominant language, mixing in English nursery words ("please," "thank you," "school," "teacher"). Pronunciation features: often substitutes 'th' sounds, elongates vowels in excited speech, and uses Krio idiomatic expressions (e.g., "I de go" for 'I am going'). He uses a lot of gestures—pointing, open-palmed offering of toys, and a characteristic triumphant clap when he accomplishes something. His tone shifts rapidly: high-pitched and sing-song when playing, low and hushed when listening to older relatives tell stories. He repeats new words several times; his favorite filler phrase is "see now" when asking for attention. He often hums tunes from a small battery radio. Clothing style: bright, hand-me-down T-shirts with cartoon prints and worn shorts; sandals in dry season, rubber boots when muddy. He is tactile: likes to touch textures (smooth mango skin, rough sackcloth).

traits: Curious: constantly inspects small objects, opens lids, and asks 'What is this?'
Playful: easily enters imaginative games, especially pretending to be a shopkeeper or footballer.
Affectionate: seeks hugs from mother and grandparents, will climb into a lap for comfort.
Stubborn: once he decides on something (a toy, a seat), he resists gentle redirection.
Observant: notices changes in household routine and remembers who brought which food.
Mimicking: copies adult mannerisms, phrases, and songs quickly.
Sociable with peers: becomes boisterous while playing with friends in the compound.
Shy with strangers: hides behind a caregiver when new people approach.
Imaginative: invents small stories about toy characters and neighborhood animals.
Emotionally expressive: shows joy loudly and frustration with tears; quickly forgives after comfort.

big_five.openness: High. Very curious, enjoys diverse play, tries new foods and songs.
big_five.conscientiousness: Low-to-Medium. Still developing routines and self-control; responds well to consistent gentle guidance.
big_five.extraversion: High. Energetic and enjoys group play, calling out to friends in the street.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Generous with sharing favorite snacks occasionally; hugs and comforts peers.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium. Sensitive to separation from primary caregiver and loud, frightening noises; generally resilient with quick recovery when soothed.

interests: Playing football (kicking a slightly deflated ball) with neighborhood children.
Listening to people sing Krio lullabies and clapping rhythms from the radio.
Pretend play as a market seller: arranging stones and scraps as 'goods'.
Chasing pigeons and watching chickens in the compound.
Splashing in small puddles after the rain.
Helping at the small family stall for a short time (pretend transactions).
Books with colorful pictures, especially animals and transport (boats, buses).
Simple puzzles and stacking cups—likes making tall towers and knocking them down.
Drawing with chunky crayons: people, suns, and soccer balls are common themes.
Listening to story-time at the community center when available.
favorite_foods_and_drinks: White rice with tomato stew and fried fish (favorite special treat).
Sweet ripe mangoes—will eat them by hand and get juice all over his face.
Boiled cassava and groundnut (peanut) sauce occasionally.
Bottled malt drinks and sour milk in small amounts as treat (sparingly).
Roasted plantain slices sold by a street vendor—loves the caramelized edges.
Plain rice with egg when he is picky or not well.
Soft bread with jam for an occasional snack.
Salted crackers as a comfort snack during play.
Warm simple porridge for breakfast when the weather is cool.
Prefers food that is warm, soft, and familiar to his palate.
toys_and_media: Small plastic cars and trucks, often shared with cousins.
A battered soft soccer ball patched with cloth.
A small plastic drum he bangs to make rhythms heard in the compound.
Sticker sheets and picture cards received occasionally.
Local children’s cartoons or music videos played on a neighbor's phone.
Simple puzzles and wooden beads for stringing (supervised).
Favorite puppet (small sock puppet) used by his grandmother at bedtime.
Enjoys watching older kids play more complex games and tries to copy them.
likes: Being held by his grandmother when sleepy.
Bright colors—red and yellow shirts make him excited.
Short songs with repetition and clapping.
Sweets on special days (buterscotch, small candies occasionally).
Routine: a predictable afternoon nap after lunch helps him feel secure.
Praise: responds eagerly to 'Good boy' and stickers as rewards.
Water play under supervision—afternoon bucket splashing.
Being included in small errands, like carrying a light bag or fetching items.
Sleeping with a thin blanket and a small stuffed object.
Watching the sunset from the balcony with the family.
dislikes: Loud sudden noises like honking horns nearby or shouting matches.
Bitter or overly spicy foods—refuses the first bite often.
Being left alone in a room with unfamiliar adults.
Baths that are too cold or when soap stings his eyes.
Cleaning up toys when he hasn’t finished a game (resists at first).
Nighttime thunderstorms—these cause him to wake frightened.
Long waits without snacks or water; becomes irritable when hungry.
habits_related_to_technology: Intermittent exposure to a neighbor's basic phone or community center tablet used very occasionally for children’s videos.
Prefers live, tactile play to screen time; watches short clips only when other children gather.
Curiosity about radios and phones—likes to press buttons and hear sounds.
Will imitate taking pictures with an empty plastic container as a pretend phone.

beliefs: My mother and grandmother know best—when they say 'no,' it usually means it's not safe or not time.
Elders should be greeted and shown respect by bringing them small gifts or by bowing slightly.
Sharing is good: when he shares candies he gets praise from adults.
School will teach him to read and write and make his parents proud.
Sleeping after lunch helps him grow strong and play better later.
If he cries and his mother comes, everything will be okay.
Boiling water and covering food keeps it clean (learned from caregivers).
Charcoal stoves and smoky rooms are uncomfortable and make his eyes water (learned observationally).
Animals are alive and can be friends if treated gently (likes chickens and neighborhood dogs).
God/Goddess/Allah (family religious references vary) listens when adults pray—religious rituals are important in his family life.
Red clothes are for festivals and special days (associates color with celebration).
If he eats mango skin seeds (playfully) they will not make him sick—family corrects this, teaching him to avoid seeds.
If he helps at the stall, small treats may follow; cooperation brings rewards.
Nighttime is for sleep; leaving lights on can make it hard to sleep (a household rule).
Thunder and lightning are loud and scary, but holding a caregiver's hand makes the fear go away.
Being polite to guests means they will bring gifts again.
Collecting 'treasures' like bottle caps is a way to make games and trade with friends.
If he gets bitten by a mosquito, it's common and adults say to put medicine or ointment on it.
If he refuses certain foods, adults will find something else he likes to keep him nourished.
Neighbors are part of family life—friends across the alley can act as extra caretakers.
It is okay to be noisy while playing outside during the day but indoors voices should be softer.
If he shares toys he will have more friends and be invited to play again.
Bravery is applauded: if he climbs a low step he gets clapping and a small prize.
If someone older tells a story, it usually has a lesson about kindness or caution.
If he gets dirty, soap and water remove the dirt and he will be cleaner and healthier.
Plants need water to stay alive—he helps water small potted plants when asked.
If an adult appears worried, it usually means something important or that someone is ill.
Saying 'thank you' makes caregivers smile and increases the chance of another treat.
Sand and mud are fun to play in, but they must be washed off before eating.
Friends who are mean are sometimes sad and need kindness rather than punishment (a lesson reinforced by grandparents).
skills: Gross motor: runs, jumps over low obstacles, kicks a ball with basic coordination, climbs low stair steps unaided.
Fine motor: holds a crayon with developing tripod grasp, can stack blocks, place puzzle pieces in simple shapes.
Language: fluent in Krio for everyday communication, uses 3-4 word English phrases intermittently, can follow 2-3 step instructions ('Wash hands, sit down, eat').
Social: takes turns during play sometimes, initiates play with peers, seeks adult approval for new behaviors.
Emotional regulation: able to be soothed by caregiver quickly after crying, uses hug or seeking adult proximity when upset.
Self-help: feeds himself with a spoon for soft foods, removes simple clothing pieces like sandals, brushes teeth with supervision.
Imaginative play: engages in role-play scenarios (shopkeeper, mother, footballer) and attributes simple stories to toys.
Observational learning: quickly copies small adult tasks like sweeping movements with a toy broom.
Problem-solving: figures out how to retrieve a toy stuck under a low shelf or how to open a loosely tied plastic bag.
Memory: recalls location of favorite toys and remembers names of close relatives and neighbors.

general: Seeks physical closeness in unfamiliar situations—often sits on grandmother's lap when guests arrive.
Repeats new words and phrases excitedly and will correct peers by imitation.
Begins and ends play with a short ritual—calling out a made-up cheer or clapping three times.
Expresses frustration by stomping feet or crying, then quickly returns to play after comfort.
Is exploratory and sometimes puts small non-food objects in mouth if unsupervised—caregivers constantly monitor this behavior.
Moves between groups of kids depending on the game and tends to gravitate toward one older cousin as a role model.
Shows preference for routine and may resist sudden changes in meal times or nap schedules.

morning: Wakes between 6:00 and 7:00 AM, often to the sound of market vendors and roosters.
Has a simple morning meal with family: porridge or bread with tea/milk.
Helps bring a small bowl to his mother and sometimes helps carry light items.
Plays quietly with blocks or watches older siblings prepare for school.
midday: Attends playschool twice a week when possible; engages in group singing, simple counting games, and outdoor play.
On other days he plays in the compound, visits neighbors, or sits in the stall area watching shoppers.
Eats the main meal with family—rice and stew or boiled cassava—and often pauses for a nap afterward.
afternoon: Short nap after lunch (30–90 minutes) depending on household schedule.
Wakes and plays outdoors: football, tag, or pretend market.
Occasionally runs errands like delivering an item to a close neighbor while supervised.
evening: Helps in small ways around the compound—standing to the side while older children clean or fetching water in a small cup.
Bath time with warm water; plays with a small plastic cup in the tub.
Dinner with family; listens to stories from grandparents, often in Krio.
Bedtime routine: brush teeth (supervised), short lullaby, and sleeps between 8:00 and 9:00 PM depending on evening activities.
weekend/occasional: Visits an aunt's house across town for special family gatherings and feasts.
Attends small community events or religious gatherings with family, wearing brighter clothing for special days.
Sometimes accompanies mother to the market where he watches, collects free samples (like fruit peels), and may briefly help with counting coins.

health.general_health: Overall good health for his age with normal growth; no diagnosed chronic conditions or developmental delays.
health.vaccinations_and_preventive: Up-to-date on routine infant and early childhood vaccinations as recorded by the local clinic (BCG, polio, DTP, measles when scheduled), though follow-up appointments occasionally missed and rescheduled.
health.common_illnesses_and_history: Has had common childhood illnesses: one episode of uncomplicated malaria last year treated at local clinic, several colds, and an ear infection treated with antibiotics. No hospitalizations beyond outpatient clinic visits.
health.nutrition: Generally eats a mixed diet available locally—protein intake is variable depending on household income and market prices. Shows healthy weight for activity level but caregivers are attentive to ensure fruit and protein on several days a week.
health.sensory_and_dental: Normal vision for close play; no formal eye exam yet. Dental: early signs of one small cavity noted by a caregiver due to sweet snacks; family plans to visit a community dental outreach when available.
health.developmental: Milestones broadly on track: runs, jumps, uses phrases, can follow simple instructions, beginning to count and recognize some letters. Fine motor skills improving with drawing and bead-threading.
health.mental_health: Emotionally typical for age: separation anxiety when parted from primary caregiver briefly, rapidly soothed by physical comfort and routine. No concerns flagged by community health worker.
health.safety_and_environment: Living in an urban compound with open drains and occasional open cooking fires—caregivers are vigilant but environmental hazards are present. Wears flip-flops to protect feet; supervised near cooking and water.
health.allergies_and_sensitivities: No known severe allergies to foods or insect stings; mild sensitivity to smoke (eyes water) from cooking fires.
health.medications_and_regular_care: No daily medications. Receives vitamin A supplementation and deworming per local health campaigns when available.

relationships.name: Fatmata Kamara
relationships.description: In her late 20s, seamstress who works from home and at times sells small clothing alterations at the nearby market. She is gentle, protective, and the main decision-maker for Adam's daily routines. She is attentive to Adam's health and learning, often singing Krio lullabies and teaching him basic counting while working.

relationships.name: Joseph Kamara
relationships.description: In his early 30s, market stall vendor who sells dried fish and small household goods. Works long hours; when home he plays football with Adam and tells short stories about his own childhood. He insists on teaching Adam basic respect for customers and neighbors and occasionally gives small coins as rewards.

relationships.name: Mama Grace
relationships.description: Lives in the same extended compound; serves as an important daytime caregiver. She cooks, supervises Adam's naps, and tells him folk tales and proverbs. She is a calming presence and the person Adam seeks when frightened.

relationships.name: Aunty Kadi
relationships.description: Helps with childcare when Fatmata works; sometimes takes Adam to the community center or to church/mosque activities depending on the family's faith mix. Teaches him simple songs and counting games.

relationships.name: Ibrahim
relationships.description: Age 10, neighborhood role model for Adam. Plays football with him, shows him how to mimic older kids' games, and sometimes helps him with simple tasks. Adam idolizes Ibrahim and tries to copy his mannerisms.

relationships.name: Neighborhood playgroup
relationships.description: A shifting group of 4–8 local children aged 3–7 who play daily in the compound. They teach one another games, share toys, and sometimes fight over prized items; reconciliation is usually mediated by adults.

relationships.name: Community nursery teacher (Madam Sia)
relationships.description: Runs the low-cost playschool twice a week. Uses songs and games to teach basic counting and sharing; praises Adam's enthusiasm and encourages turn-taking.

relationships.name: Market vendor neighbors
relationships.description: Many adults in the market know Adam and often give him small candies or play briefly with him. They provide informal supervision and are part of his wider socialization.

relationships.name: Playmate Nene
relationships.description: A neighbor girl aged 4 who often partners with Adam in pretend market play and shares snacks. They sometimes form a 'team' during street football.

other_facts: Born at the city maternity clinic in Freetown with a normal delivery; birth weight within expected range.
Nicknamed 'Adi' by family members; the name is used affectionately by grandparents and cousins.
His first word was 'Mama' and he used it consistently from about 9 months.
Adam learned to walk at about 12 months and began running confidently by age 2.
He once got lost briefly at a crowded market stall as a toddler; a shopkeeper recognized him from past visits and escorted him back to his mother—an event that reinforced vigilance among caregivers.
Has a small plush sock puppet given by his grandmother that he uses at bedtime for imaginative conversations.
Favorite routine: clapping with his grandmother to the rhythm of a radio jingle every evening.
Attended his first extended family wedding at age 3 and enjoyed dancing to loud drums, though he fell asleep during the late evening.
Is involved in basic household rituals: washing hands before meals (encouraged by caregivers) and saying a short pre-meal phrase common in the household.
Remembers and recognizes the faces of the community clinic nurses and waves at them when he sees them.
Was introduced to counting with small stones and seeds; can reliably count to ten when reciting with a teacher.
Has a vivid memory of a seaside visit with his family—loved picking up shells and watching boats, but was wary of larger waves.
Experienced a brief episode of conjunctivitis once and learned to keep his hands away from his eyes after explanations from caregivers.
Shows a specific fear of loud motorbike engines after an incident where one passed very close during play.
Enjoys wearing a small red T-shirt that belonged to his older cousin; it is his 'special shirt' for playdates.
Observes small household rituals such as removing shoes before entering certain rooms depending on relatives' customs.
Has a modest collection of bottle caps and colorful wrappers kept in a small tin for making 'treasures' to play with.
Occasionally imitates adult bargaining voices at the market to entertain neighbors and encourage tips of candies.
Once helped his mother fetch water in a small plastic container and proudly presented it to her—received a loud cheer.
Knows the route to the nearest community center and identifies it by a painted sign and the sounds of children's laughter.
Has a running joke with his cousin about pretending to be the 'stall owner' who gives away the best mango slices.
Was photographed for a small family album during a naming celebration and enjoys looking at the printed photo when presented with it.
Attends occasional short religious or cultural songs performed by elders and participates by clapping and repeating simple phrases.
Has an emerging frustration tolerance—on bad days he may cry loudly for 10–15 minutes before calming with a hug.
Has an early attachment object: a small cloth scrap given by his mother at six months which he still seeks at nap time.
Participated in a local children's health outreach where he received vitamin drops and a sticker; he brings up the sticker as a badge of pride.
Sometimes imitates adult cooking motions with an empty pot and wooden spoon, pretending to make stew for the family.
Enjoys being given small responsibilities like placing clean dishes on a low shelf; these tasks boost his confidence and sense of belonging.
Has been taught a few short proverbs by his grandmother, such as 'small hands also can help,' which he repeats proudly.
Experienced a minor scrape on the knee while playing; the event taught him to be more careful climbing low walls for a short while.
Has a routine of checking under his bed for 'hidden treasure' before sleeping—part of a game he invented with cousins.
Has been present at community meetings where adults discuss market prices; though he doesn't understand all, he associates raised voices with serious matters.
His family sometimes moves small items between rooms during the day for privacy; he understands which spots are 'no play' zones.
Is learning to say 'excuse me' and 'please' in both Krio and simple English in everyday interactions.
Dreams and imaginary play occasionally include flying—he'll leap off a low step and shout 'I fly!' while cousins cheer.
Has been given small pocket money (coins) on special days by a visiting relative and learned early lessons about saving versus spending.
Is fascinated by the market's colorful fabrics and will point out prints and ask for explanations of colors and patterns.
Participated in a simple handwashing demonstration at playschool that included a song—he now performs the song before meals with peers.
Understands basic safety teaching: "Don't touch hot pots" and "Hold an adult's hand when crossing the street," which he repeats to younger children as a game.
Has a playful rivalry with a neighbor child over who can kick the ball further; these contests end in laughter and mutual teasing rather than serious conflict.
Was once comforted by a visiting neighbor who brought a small toy car when he was sick, strengthening community bonds and Adam's trust in neighbors.
